review: Its hard to explain in words the ambience and mouth watering taste of authentic cuisine you will get for an early morning breakfast in this place. Its open by 7 a.m., so if you time it well, there is no better place for a sumptuous...and gratifying-in-everyway breakfast than Hela Bojun in and around Dambulla. There are two in the vicinity of Dambulla. But this place is unique as you can sit out under a summer hut. There is only Vegetarian Sri Lankan, so don't expect a breakfast with Scramble eggs and sausages. Who would want that anyway once you have tasted this array of authentic Sri Lankan breakfast. and gratifying-in-everyway breakfast than Hela Bojun in and around Dambulla. There are two in the vicinity of Dambulla. But this place is unique as you can sit out under a summer hut. There is only Vegetarian Sri Lankan, so don't expect a breakfast with Scramble eggs and sausages. Who would want that anyway once you have tasted this array of authentic Sri Lankan breakfast. :)

Absolutely local and delicious. Lovely team, great concept, great products, proper Sri Lankan experience as all the food prepared is fresh and from local recipe. By going their you also contribute and support womanâ€™s empowerment. And how good is it to eat local but changing...a bit from curries and trying so many different dishes! The location is also really pleasant surrounded by forest and their plants/veggie garden. Beautiful atmosphe a bit from curries and trying so many different dishes! The location is also really pleasant surrounded by forest and their plants/veggie garden. Beautiful atmosphere.

This is a great place to try Sri Lankan snacks and sweets. The ladies do not speak much English but are eager to help as much as they can. Mostly we just pointed at what we fancied and at approx 50RPS an item you can...try a little of everything. We had string hoppers (vermicelli noodles) with coconut sambal, dosas (rice pancake) with coconut chutney  and curry soup, vadas (friend lentil patties), roti as well as some sweet items all washed down with fresh fruit juice. A fun and inexpensive introduction to Sri Lankan fo try a little of everything. We had string hoppers (vermicelli noodles) with coconut sambal, dosas (rice pancake) with coconut chutney  and curry soup, vadas (friend lentil patties), roti as well as some sweet items all washed down with fresh fruit juice. A fun and inexpensive introduction to Sri Lankan food.

Just left this was really good we ordered the Masala and the string khobbaz I think that was the name and daaaamn it was the best thing I ate since we arrived to Dambulla strongly recommended the prices are so so good too my order...was 25 rupees and the masala was 35 rupee was 25 rupees and the masala was 35 rupees ğŸ˜

Donâ€™t let the name discourage you; this actually is a traditional food sales centre. 
(The place is run by a government agency, itâ€™s not about profits)
You can try some Sri Lankan bites costing 10-50rs each. Sweet and savory are all mixed together, be careful....The restaurant is self service, pay the ladies when ordering. Then there is a nice garden with a small pond to sit down to eat - and go back for mo The restaurant is self service, pay the ladies when ordering. Then there is a nice garden with a small pond to sit down to eat - and go back for more.

Believe me when I say this is the proper stuff! I am Sri-Lankan after-all! 

We visited the Nuwara Eliya food centre and enjoyed Pitty, Bellu Flowers tea and Kurakkan drinks. They had an incredible selection of Roti, spring hoppers and curries. This is a great...initiative from the government that has been rolled out around the island. 

All the monies go to help the families of those who are struggling. The ladies I spoke to said that it really helps them earn extra cash and learn new skills to trade. If you pass by one of these, do take a look and have some food - you will not be disappoint initiative from the government that has been rolled out around the island. 

All the monies go to help the families of those who are struggling. The ladies I spoke to said that it really helps them earn extra cash and learn new skills to trade. If you pass by one of these, do take a look and have some food - you will not be disappointed!

Without any prior knowledge of this place, we stopped in here not knowing what to expect....it was a pleasant surprise where we had a huge choice of local foods to try...and learn about. All yummy and cheap as as chips!

My friend had read about this place, so we decided to try it out. The food was delicious, freshly cooked by women, typical Sri Lankan food, with our experience at Pearl White Villa in Uduwalawe and the Big Belly in Mirissa it was the best...food we had. Set in a garden with tables to take the food to, it is a highly recommended place in Sri La food we had. Set in a garden with tables to take the food to, it is a highly recommended place in Sri Lanka

We stopped here for lunch one day and it was so good that we came back again the next day (apparently it is popular locally as well, our trishaw driver picked up a takeaway that we dropped off to his wife after lunch). Lots of...local foods to try, at prices low enough to taste multiple things, and very friendly and helpful women running the stan local foods to try, at prices low enough to taste multiple things, and very friendly and helpful women running the stands.

This place is located near the dambulla habarana main road. You can have good Sri Lankan foods for cheap price. Specially traditional foods. Quality is in good level. You can see how they are preparing without the hidden kitchen.
This is lead by the Agriculture department of Sri Lanka. You can have the good quality traditional foods for cheap price. You can see how they prepare it. Its delicious.

This Traditional Food Centre is a fascinating place where local ladies engage in cooking for visitors as a means of demonstrating local foods and generating income. It is frequented by many local people and is a truly splendid way of tasting genuine local home cooked...food as very reasonable prices whilst contributing to the income of the ladies. The kitchen is set in lovely grounds with indigenous trees and plants and the dining tables have been established under the trees in shady spots. You go to the long counter where you can watch the food being prepared and choose your dishes. Signs are not in English so choice is somewhat random depending on what you can see in front of you. All dishes are vegetarian and prices incredibly low. We wished our command of Sinhala was better as it was not possible to discuss the foods and ingredients with the ladies. They do a tremendous job and we hope the centre does really we food as very reasonable prices whilst contributing to the income of the ladies. All dishes are vegetarian and prices incredibly low. We wished our command of Sinhala was better as it was not possible to discuss the foods and ingredients with the ladies. They do a tremendous job and we hope the centre does really well.

Recommended by our Sri Lankan tour guide we stopped for lunch and had one of the best food experiences in Sri Lanka.
This is not a tourist place, but we were very welcome.
Locals preparing and selling local vegetables. Highly recommended to stop for lunch...he here!

This place is like a row of counters with different foods, where you choose and pay for your food at the counter(s) and then take your plate(s) to one of the tables in the lovely big garden or ask for it to be take-away. 
Only...the names of the dishes are written in English but none of the ladies spoke English well enough to explain the ingredients so you just pick what looks good and hope for the best :)

The food was absolutely delicious and prepared right in front of you - hoppers, dosas, amazing (and HOT) jackfruit balls, many fried dough foods, both sweet and savoury - vadai were incredibly tasty but obviously not healthy as itâ€™s a grease-and-carbs fest :) All dishes are vegetarian. And the price is ridiculously low compared to any other place weâ€™ve tried. 

The only drink they had on offer was homemade soymilk.

Even though the kitchen is clean (again - you watch every meal being prepared right in front of you), I was a bit nervous because the tables and chairs in the garden are not really cleaned, they donâ€™t have cutlery so you have to eat with your hands (not sure if itâ€™s always like that, our driver asked for spoons and they had none so you might want to take one with you) and the place where you can wash your hands outside the restaurant has only cold water and a small piece of ordinary soap (not liquid soap). We had no problems later, though, and this was one of the best experiences weâ€™ve h the names of the dishes are written in English but none of the ladies spoke English well enough to explain the ingredients so you just pick what looks good and hope for the best :)

We had no problems later, though, and this was one of the best experiences weâ€™ve had.
Great way to experience local cuisine at a very reasonable price. It's no open every night so be sure to check in advance.
We got recommendation for this restaurant from our host. It is a nice place with very reasonable prices, food tasted very good.  I would come back to this place.

Really nice place. 
You need to go to the second floor, the shop on the pictures is not a part of the actual restaurant. 
The restaurant is nice, calm, pretty and has a good atmosphere. 
The food was really great and the service was good.

It might not look much from the outside but this place is a gem in an otherwise diabolical food scene on Dambulla.
We ate here twice on a two night stay in Dambulla as they offer a welcome alternative to the typical Sri Lanka buffet...restaurant. It looks like a cafeteria yet is full of locals so we knew we were in the right place.
There is a restaurant upstairs which looks on the expensive side yet it's not. You can order what is from the more local menu downstairs and more. On our first night  we had prawn kadai and chicken masala with soft drinks. Both were excellent and finished off with a dessert downstairs. The bill came to less than 2000SLR (Â£5). We honestly couldn't believe the price. 
The next night we tried and tried to find somewhere with more of a restaurant vibe, however after looking endlessly on TripAdvisor, Google, etc there was no where that took our fancy. Dambulla is not the place for a foodie.
The second night we had a mixture of curry, naan, samosas, rotti, biryani and Mongolian stew. It was all fantastic and we sat downstairs. It's nothing fancy but the food outweighs everything. This meal with two ginger beers cost 2600SLR (Â£6.5 restaurant. It looks like a cafeteria yet is full of locals so we knew we were in the right place.

Great Kottu, and very friendly staff! Great for children. Reasonably priced, with a fun bakery downstairs too. Lucky, as it was one of the few places that was open on our visit.

I was in search of a Sri Lankan kottu and was brought here on recommendation from my taxi driver.
I enjoyed the chicken kottu but was not overwhelmed by it, especially since the few pieces of chicken in the kottu were very dry and over...cooked.
The prawn biryani my husband ordered was also not overwhelming in flavour especially since the prawns were more shrimp in size, and not flavoursome, but merely an additional afterthought to the biryani rice.
Admittedly we visited at an awkward time so the restaurant had no ambience.
But at least I got to try my first kottu in Dambul cooked.
The prawn biryani my husband ordered was also not overwhelming in flavour especially since the prawns were more shrimp in size, and not flavoursome, but merely an additional afterthought to the biryani rice.
Admittedly we visited at an awkward time so the restaurant had no ambience.
But at least I got to try my first kottu in Dambulla!

We went there for dinner at around 8 pm and were obviously too late because the curries section was down to 3 choices, many empty pots. The baked goods selection, however, was nice - good variety of savoury and sweet stuff. Most things we tried...were of good quali were of good quality.
Due to inadequate understanding of English also, we had a problem. We could not get them to understand how to get what food.

I had been a regular customer of Benthota Bake house Dambulla. During this period Several times I hapend to experience some worst services I have had. Ladies who are there to serve foods and in the front counter do not know how to treat people....ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘Teri ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘Terible

The place is clean, but the waiters can't speak a word in English, and after an everlasting waiting we'had understood that he didn't sign our order..ok we can wait.. But i can't tolerate they push me cuz it's closing time, since it's their fault me...still sitting h still sitting here

I ate on the second floor of the Bake House for dinner. I thoroughly enjoyed all of the meals that were served to me and the waiters were lovely. Each meal had different unique flavours and met all of my standards of a delicious meal....I would definitely eat there aga I would definitely eat there again.

I had dinner on the first floor which was full of the local people. It was a bit hectic but it was good chance to experience a little bit of local atmosphere.
Price was reasonable and portion of food was big. 
I had kottu and...then had milk tea as people seemed to have milk tea a lot.
I recommended you have milk tea without sugar or at least ask them to put just little bit of sugar.

If your hungry, stop past and get a snack. They serve a large variety of foods, and also have a restaurant attached for a proper meal.

Hi,
         Its real recommended food outlet of the Dambulla city area and available local & tourist meals with real good price and clean. I'm also visited several times to this place. This is food expired for bakery .
Thanks.

We went to the dining room next to the bakehouse to have lunch. It was okay and definitely great value for money since the portions were big. BUT: I had way better food in Sri Lanka. Besides the dining room the bakery is a must-go....We ordered three different kinds of products and all were genuinely great :) dining room: 2 stars. Bakery: 5 stars. This is why I ended up with We ordered three different kinds of products and all were genuinely great :) dining room: 2 stars. Bakery: 5 stars. This is why I ended up with 3.
We had a really nice Sri Lankan breakfast here today. It comprised of Pittu & bread with a variety of curries. It was plentiful & reasonably priced.
